questions.text: Failure of closure of rostral neuropore at 25th day leads to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anencephaly:

  • Failure of closure of the rostral neuropore at around the 25th day of embryonic development leads to the condition known as anencephaly.
  • Anencephaly is a severe congenital malformation characterized by the absence of a major portion of the brain and skull.

Incorrect Options:

Option  A - Hydranencephaly: Hydranencephaly, marked by near-total or complete absence of cerebral hemispheres, isn't specifically due to the failure of rostral neuropore closure.

Option B - Rachischisis: Rachischisis is a severe type of spina bifida where the neural tube doesn't close along the spine's entire length, not involving rostral neuropore closure.

Option D - Spina bifida: Spina bifida, involves incomplete neural tube closure, leading to spinal cord defects, but it's not directly linked to rostral neuropore closure failure.

questions.text: At what level is the inferior scapular angle located?
questions.solution:
Correct option: D

  • Explanation: The inferior scapular angle is at the level of the seventh thoracic vertebra (T7).
  • The scapula, also known as the shoulder blade, is a flat triangular bone that is located on the posterior aspect of the thorax.
  • The inferior angle of the scapula is the lowermost point of the bone, and it lies at approximately the level of the eighth thoracic vertebra.

Incorrect option:

Option A. T2: The inferior scapular angle is not at the level of the second thoracic vertebra (T2). It is located at a lower level in the thoracic region.

Option B. T4: The inferior scapular angle is not at the level of the fourth thoracic vertebra (T4). It is located lower in the thoracic region.

Option C. T6: The inferior scapular angle is not at the level of the sixth thoracic vertebra (T6). It is located lower in the thoracic region.

questions.text: The rotator cuff includes the following muscles all except;
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C.

  • Teres major: The teres major muscle is not considered part of the rotator cuff. It is a larger muscle located on the posterior side of the upper arm and is responsible for adduction and medial rotation of the arm.

Incorrect Options:

Options A. Supraspinatus: The supraspinatus muscle is one of the four muscles that make up the rotator cuff. It is located on the posterior side of the shoulder joint and assists in shoulder abduction.

Options B. Infraspinatus: The infraspinatus muscle is another muscle that is part of the rotator cuff. It is situated below the supraspinatus muscle and is responsible for lateral rotation of the arm.

Options D. Teres minor: The teres minor muscle is also included in the rotator cuff. It is located below the infraspinatus muscle and aids in lateral rotation of the arm.

questions.text: Which single muscle is involved in the actions of arm's flexion, adduction and medial rotation?
questions.solution:
Correct option C:

  • Pectoralis major muscle is involved in the actions of arm's flexion, adduction, and medial rotation.
  • It is a large muscle located in the chest region and plays a significant role in various movements of the shoulder joint.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Serratus Anterior: This muscle is primarily involved in protraction and upward rotation of the scapula.

Option  C. Pectoralis minor: This muscle assists in stabilizing the scapula and has a role in protraction and downward rotation of the scapula.

Option  D. Subclavius: This muscle helps to stabilize and depress the clavicle.

questions.text: One of the nerves supplying the upper limb, the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm, supplying the skin overlying the posterior border of the deltoid muscle as well as covering the long head of the triceps, is a branch of:
questions.solution:
Correct option: D

  • The axillary nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin overlying the posterior border of the deltoid muscle and extends down to cover the long head of the triceps muscle.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve supplies motor innervation to the anterior compartment muscles of the arm and does not supply the mentioned sensory area.

Option B. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies sensory innervation to the posterior aspect of the arm but does not specifically provide innervation to the mentioned area.

Option C. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily supplies sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the hand and does not innervate the mentioned area.

questions.text: Which muscle originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C

The muscle that originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus is the pronator teres muscle. The pronator teres is located in the forearm and is responsible for pronating the forearm, which means rotating the forearm from a palm-up (supine) position to a palm-down (pronated) position.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Supinator: The supinator muscle, situated in the forearm's posterior compartment, isn't rooted in the medial epicondyle of the humerus.

Option B. Pronator quadratus: The pronator quadratus muscle, deep in the forearm, isn't linked to the medial epicondyle of the humerus.

Option D. Brachioradialis: The brachioradialis muscle originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus, not the medial epicondyle.

questions.text: An injury to the shown area can lead to fracture of which bone
questions.solution:
Correct Option  B: 

  • Injuries to the anatomical snuffbox can lead to fractures of the scaphoid bone, which is one of the carpal bones located in the wrist.
  • The scaphoid bone is vulnerable to fractures due to its location and shape.
  • Fractures of the scaphoid bone can result from a fall onto an outstretched hand, particularly when the force is transmitted through the thumb.

Incorrect Options :

Option A. Lunate: The lunate is another carpal bone, but it is not directly associated with the anatomical snuffbox.

Option C. Hamate: The hamate is a carpal bone located on the ulnar side of the wrist and is not directly associated with the anatomical snuffbox.

Option D. Trapezium: The trapezium is a carpal bone located at the base of the thumb, but it is not part of the anatomical snuffbox

questions.text: A patient presents with hypothenar muscle wasting and loss of sensation of medial one and a half digits. Which nerve is involved
questions.solution:
Correct option  C. Ulnar.

  • The symptoms described, hypothenar muscle wasting and loss of sensation of the medial one and a half digits, indicate the involvement of the ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve is responsible for the innervation of the hypothenar muscles (located in the palm of the hand) and provides sensory innervation to the medial one and a half digits (the little finger and half of the ring finger).

Incorrect Options :

Option A. Musculocutaneous: The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the anterior arm muscles but not the hypothenar muscles or sensation to the described digits.

Option B. Radial: The radial nerve innervates the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm and does not supply the hypothenar muscles or provide sensory innervation to the described digits.

Option D. Median: The median nerve supplies the muscles of the anterior compartment of the forearm and does not innervate the hypothenar muscles or provide sensory innervation to the described digits.

questions.text: Testicular artery is a branch of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A

  • Explanation: The testicular artery is a branch of the abdominal aorta.
  • It arises from the anterior aspect of the abdominal aorta just below the origin of the renal arteries.
  • It travels inferiorly to reach the testes and provides the arterial blood supply to the testicles.

Incorrect options :

Option B. Common iliac artery: The common iliac artery is a vessel that arises from the abdominal aorta and bifurcates into the internal and external iliac arteries. It does not directly supply the testicular artery.

Option C. External iliac artery: The external iliac artery is a branch of the common iliac artery and supplies the lower limb. It does not supply the testicular artery.

Option D. Internal iliac artery: The internal iliac artery is a branch of the common iliac artery and supplies the pelvis and pelvic organs. It does not supply the testicular artery.

questions.text: Deep inguinal ring is formed in:
questions.solution:
Correct option: D.

  • The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia, which is the innermost layer of the abdominal wall.
  • It is located above and medial to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament.
  • The deep inguinal ring is an important anatomical landmark in the inguinal region and serves as the starting point of the inguinal canal.

Incorrect options:

Option A. External oblique aponeurosis: The external oblique aponeurosis contributes to the formation of the superficial inguinal ring, which is a separate structure from the deep inguinal ring.

Option B. Internal oblique aponeurosis: The internal oblique aponeurosis also contributes to the formation of the superficial inguinal ring, not the deep inguinal ring.

Option C. Transversus abdominis: The transversus abdominis muscle lies deep to the internal oblique muscle and its aponeurosis. It does not directly contribute to the formation of the deep inguinal ring.

questions.text: Inguinal ligament is formed due to
questions.solution:
Correct option B. 

  • The inguinal ligament is formed due to the external oblique aponeurosis.
  • The external oblique muscle of the abdominal wall gives rise to a broad flat tendon called the external oblique aponeurosis.
  • The lower border of the external oblique aponeurosis forms the inguinal ligament, which extends from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) to the pubic tubercle.
  • The inguinal ligament plays a role in supporting the structures of the inguinal region.

Incorrect options :

Option A. Cremaster muscle: The cremaster muscle is a thin muscle that covers the spermatic cord. It is not involved in the formation of the inguinal ligament.

Option C. Internal oblique aponeurosis: The internal oblique muscle contributes to the formation of the conjoint tendon, which is a thickening of the transversalis fascia. It does not directly form the inguinal ligament.

Option D. Transversus abdominis: The transversus abdominis muscle is the deepest muscle of the abdominal wall. It does not contribute to the formation of the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: Abduction at the hip joint is done by
questions.solution:
Correct option : B. 

  • Explanation: Abduction at the hip joint, which refers to moving the leg away from the midline of the body, is primarily performed by the gluteus medius muscle.
  • The gluteus medius is a broad, thick muscle located on the lateral aspect of the hip. It acts as a powerful abductor of the hip joint and plays a crucial role in maintaining stability during activities such as walking and running.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Gluteus maximus: The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle of the buttocks and primarily functions in extending and externally rotating the hip joint. While it can assist in abduction, it is not the primary muscle responsible for this movement.

Option C. Obturator internus: The obturator internus is a deep muscle of the hip that acts as an external rotator of the hip joint. It does not contribute significantly to hip abduction.

Option D. Quadratus femoris: The quadratus femoris is a deep muscle of the hip that assists in hip joint stabilization and contributes to hip rotation. It is not a primary muscle involved in hip abduction.

questions.text: Identify the marked tendon in the diagram:
questions.solution:
Correct option :A

  • Explanation: In the provided diagram, the marked tendon corresponds to the Extensor hallucis longus.
  • The Extensor hallucis longus is a muscle located in the anterior compartment of the leg. It originates from the middle third of the fibula and inserts onto the base of the distal phalanx of the great toe.
  • Its main action is to extend (dorsiflex) the great toe at the metatarsophalangeal joint and assist in dorsiflexion of the ankle joint.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Flexor hallucis longus: This muscle is located in the posterior compartment of the leg and is responsible for flexing the great toe.

Option C. Extensor digitorum longus: This muscle is also located in the anterior compartment of the leg and is responsible for extending (dorsiflexing) the lateral four toes.

Option D. Tibialis anterior: This muscle is located in the anterior compartment of the leg and is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot

questions.text: How many chest compressions per minute are performed during CPR in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 100-120 per minute:

  • Chest compressions are critical to providing circulation to the heart and brain during CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation). The recommended rate for chest compressions in adult CPR is 100-120 compressions per minute, which ensures adequate blood flow to vital organs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 30-50 per minute: This range is incorrect as it is too low for effective CPR.

Option B - 50-72 per minute: This range is also incorrect as it is below the recommended rate for effective chest compressions.

Option D - 120-200 per minute: This range is too high and not recommended for effective CPR. An excessive compression rate may compromise the quality of compressions.

questions.text: Spinal anaesthesia in an adult is given at this level:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - L3-L4:

  • Spinal anesthesia is a regional anesthesia technique used to block sensation and motor function in a specific area of the body. The level at which spinal anesthesia is typically administered in adults is the L3-L4 vertebral level. The anesthetic agent is injected into the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the subarachnoid space at this level, allowing for selective anesthesia below that level.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - T12-L1: This level is higher than the usual level for spinal anesthesia and is not commonly used.

Option B - L1-L2: This level is also higher than the usual level for spinal anesthesia and is not commonly used.

Option D - L5-S1: This level is lower than the usual level for spinal anesthesia and is not typically used for this technique.

questions.text: Colour of nitrous oxide cylinder is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A 

  • Nitrous oxide cylinders are typically color-coded for easy identification and safety purposes. The color of a nitrous oxide cylinder is blue. This color helps to differentiate it from other gas cylinders.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Blue body with white shoulder - This option describes a different color pattern that is not commonly associated with nitrous oxide cylinders.

Option C: White - This option is incorrect as white is not the typical color for nitrous oxide cylinders.

Option D: Black - This option is also incorrect as black is not the typical color for nitrous oxide cylinders.

questions.text: The duration of spinal anaesthesia is based directly on:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dose:

  • The duration of spinal anesthesia, which refers to the period of anesthesia achieved by administering local anesthetics into the subarachnoid space, is primarily based on the dose of the anesthetic agent used. The higher the dose, the longer the duration of anesthesia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Height: The duration of spinal anesthesia is not directly influenced by a person's height.

Option C - Age: The duration of spinal anesthesia is not directly determined by a person's age.

Option D - Total body fat: The duration of spinal anesthesia is not directly related to a person's total body fat.

questions.text: Enolase is inhibited by which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NaF:

  • Enolase is an enzyme involved in the glycolytic pathway, specifically in the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate. It plays a crucial role in energy metabolism.

Incorrect Options 

Option B - Fluoroacetate: Fluoroacetate inhibits the enzyme aconitase, which is involved in the citric acid cycle (also known as the Krebs cycle or TCA cycle). It does not directly inhibit enolase.

Option C - Iodoacetate: Iodoacetate is an inhibitor of the enzyme glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), which is an enzyme involved in the glycolytic pathway. It does not directly inhibit enolase.

Option D - Potassium oxalate: Potassium oxalate is not known to directly inhibit enolase. It is primarily used as an anticoagulant for blood collection.

questions.text: Maple syrup urine disease is due to a deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - α-keto acid dehydrogenase:

  • Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme α-keto acid dehydrogenase.

Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Collagen is rich in which amino acid:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Glycine

  • Glycine plays a critical role in collagen structure and function. It is the smallest amino acid and has a unique structural property that allows it to fit tightly into the triple helical structure of collagen.
  • Glycine residues are found at every third position in the collagen polypeptide chain, allowing for the close packing of collagen molecules and the formation of stable triple helices.

Incorrect Options :

Option B - Arginine: While arginine is an important amino acid involved in various biological processes, it is not the amino acid that is predominantly present in collagen.

Option C - Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is an aromatic amino acid, but it is not the primary amino acid found in collagen.

Option D - Tyrosine: Tyrosine is another aromatic amino acid, but it is not the primary amino acid found in collagen.

questions.text: Nitric oxide is derived from:
questions.solution:
Correct option : A

  • Arginine. Nitric oxide (NO) is derived from the amino acid arginine.
  • Nitric oxide is a signaling molecule and a potent vasodilator involved in various physiological processes such as regulation of blood pressure, immune response, and neurotransmission. It is synthesized in the body by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS), which converts arginine into nitric oxide and citrulline.

Incorrect options :

Option B. Histidine: Histidine is an essential amino acid involved in various biological processes, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

Option C. Glycine: Glycine is an amino acid that plays a crucial role in collagen structure and various other biological functions. However, it is not the precursor for nitric oxide synthesis.

Option D. Aspartate: Aspartate is an amino acid involved in protein synthesis and various metabolic pathways, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

questions.text: Which coenzyme is required for the de novo synthesis of fatty acids?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NADPH:

  • De novo synthesis of fatty acids requires NADPH as a coenzyme. During fatty acid synthesis, NADPH provides reducing equivalents necessary for converting acetyl-CoA into fatty acids. It is utilized by fatty acid synthase (FAS) to reduce intermediate compounds, facilitating fatty acid synthesis.

Incorrect options :

Option B - TPP (Thiamine pyrophosphate) - TPP is involved in decarboxylation reactions but not directly in de novo fatty acid synthesis.

Option C - FAD (Flavin adenine dinucleotide) - FAD functions as a hydrogen and electron carrier but is not specifically required for fatty acid synthesis.

Option D - NAD (Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) - NAD participates in redox reactions but is not the coenzyme required for de novo fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: Except for which of the following, all are cofactors for Dehydrogenase?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - SAM

  • SAM (S-adenosylmethionine). SAM is not a cofactor for dehydrogenase enzymes. It is involved in a variety of methylation reactions as a methyl group donor, playing a role in epigenetic regulation and other biochemical processes
  • Dehydrogenase enzymes are involved in oxidation-reduction reactions, where they catalyze the transfer of hydrogen atoms or electrons from a substrate to an electron acceptor. These enzymes typically require specific cofactors to facilitate their activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - NADP (Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate): NADP is a cofactor that is commonly involved in oxidation-reduction reactions, including those catalyzed by dehydrogenase enzymes. It serves as an electron carrier during these reactions.

Option B - FAD (Flavin adenine dinucleotide): FAD is another cofactor commonly used by dehydrogenase enzymes. It acts as a carrier of electrons and facilitates the transfer of hydrogen atoms during oxidation-reduction reactions.

Option C - NAD (Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide): NAD is yet another cofactor that plays a vital role in the activity of dehydrogenase enzymes. It serves as an electron carrier and participates in oxidation-reduction reactions.

questions.text: Which glycogen storage disease is associated with the alkaline pH of skeletal muscle after strenuous exercise?
questions.solution:
Correct option:A

  • Mc Ardle's disease: After strenuous exercise, the alkaline pH of skeletal muscle is observed in Mc Ardle's disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type V. Mc Ardle's disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme myophosphorylase, which is responsible for breaking down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate in muscle tissue. Without this enzyme, glycogen cannot be efficiently broken down, leading to impaired energy production during exercise. As a result, the muscle relies on anaerobic glycolysis, leading to the accumulation of lactic acid and subsequent alkaline pH.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Von Gierke's disease: Von Gierke's disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type I, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. This enzyme is involved in the final step of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, converting glucose-6-phosphate to glucose. However, Von Gierke's disease does not result in an alkaline pH of skeletal muscle after strenuous exercise.

Option C. Her's disease: Her's disease, or glycogen storage disease type VI, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme liver glycogen phosphorylase. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen into glucose in the liver. However, Her's disease does not lead to an alkaline pH in skeletal muscle after strenuous exercise.

Option D. Pompe's disease: Pompe's disease, or glycogen storage disease type II, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase (GAA), which is responsible for breaking down glycogen into glucose in lysosomes. Pompe's disease primarily affects cardiac and skeletal muscles. While Pompe's disease can result in exercise intolerance and muscle weakness, it does not cause an alkaline pH in skeletal muscle after strenuous exercise.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent lipid phase antioxidant?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Vitamin E:

  • Among the options given, Vitamin E is the most potent lipid phase antioxidant. It has a crucial role in protecting cell membranes and lipoproteins from oxidative damage by scavenging lipid-based free radicals.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Vitamin A: While important, it's not the most potent lipid phase antioxidant. Vitamin E holds that distinction due to its stronger antioxidant activity in lipids.

Option C - Vitamin C: A potent antioxidant, but its primary action is in the aqueous phase, not the lipid phase, so it's not considered the most potent lipid phase antioxidant.

Option D - Vitamin K: Vital for blood clotting and bone health, but it's not recognized for antioxidant properties in lipids, hence not the most potent lipid phase antioxidant.

questions.text: Wernicke encephalopathy caused by deficiency of which vitamin?
questions.solution:
Correct option A. 

  • Wernicke encephalopathy is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine). Thiamine is necessary for normal neurological functioning, and its deficiency can result in various neurological symptoms.

Incorrect options

Options: B. Vit B2 (Riboflavin): Wernicke encephalopathy is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine), not Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin). While both vitamins are essential for normal neurological functioning, a deficiency of Vitamin B1 specifically leads to Wernicke encephalopathy.

Option C. Vit B7 (Biotin): Wernicke encephalopathy is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine), not Vitamin B7 (Biotin). Vitamin B7 is involved in various metabolic processes but is not associated with Wernicke encephalopathy.

Option D. Vit B12 (Cobalamin): Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms, but it is not the cause of Wernicke encephalopathy. Wernicke encephalopathy is specifically associated with a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine).

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most specific biomarker for pheochromocytoma, a rare tumor that typically arises in the chromaffin cells (pheochromocytes) of the adrenal gland and is usually benign?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - VMA

  • Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) is the most specific biomarker for pheochromocytoma. It is a metabolite of catecholamines, which are secreted by pheochromocytomas. Measurement of VMA levels in urine is a common diagnostic test for pheochromocytoma.

Incorrect options

Options: B - Catecholamine: Catecholamines, such as epinephrine and norepinephrine, are secreted by pheochromocytomas, but they are not the most specific biomarker. Measurement of catecholamines in urine or blood can support the diagnosis but is not considered the most specific test.

Option C - 5-HIAA (5-Hydroxyindoleacetic acid): 5-HIAA is a metabolite of serotonin and is mainly used as a biomarker for carcinoid tumors, not pheochromocytomas. It is not the most specific biomarker for pheochromocytoma.

Option D - Serotonin: Serotonin is not the most specific biomarker for pheochromocytoma. While serotonin-secreting tumors (carcinoid tumors) can occasionally arise from chromaffin cells, the most specific biomarker for pheochromocytoma is VMA (Vanillylmandelic acid)

questions.text: Which of the following releases histamine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mast cells

  • Mast cells are the primary cells responsible for releasing histamine. They are involved in allergic reactions and immune responses, and the release of histamine from mast cells contributes to the symptoms of allergic conditions.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Eosinophils: While eosinophils can release certain inflammatory mediators, such as leukotrienes and cytokines, they do not release histamine.

Option C - T-cells: T-cells are a type of white blood cell that plays a crucial role in adaptive immune responses. They help coordinate immune responses and target specific pathogens or infected cells.

Option D - NK cells: NK cells are primarily involved in cell-mediated cytotoxicity and cytokine production. They do not release histamine, which is predominantly released by mast cells.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a history of fever and oral ulcers and has developed erythematous lesions on her face. Comment on the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) SLE

 

Explanation:

 

A 25-year-old female with:

  • Fever

  • Oral ulcers

  • Erythematous facial lesions

These features are classic for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), especially when the facial rash involves the malar (butterfly) region — the cheeks and bridge of the nose — sparing the nasolabial folds.

Feature Description
Demographics Young females (childbearing age)
Fever Common systemic symptom
Oral ulcers Typically painless
Malar rash Butterfly-shaped rash over cheeks and nose
Photosensitivity Rash worsens with sun exposure
Other features Arthritis, serositis, renal involvement, ANA/anti-dsDNA positivity

 

Dermatomyositis (Option B): Presents with heliotrope rash (purple discoloration around eyes), Gottron’s papules, and proximal muscle weakness — not prominent in this case.

 

Melasma (Option C): Brownish hyperpigmented macules over sun-exposed areas, especially face; no fever or oral ulcers.

 

Rosacea (Option D): Facial erythema, telangiectasias, flushing, and pustules; typically in older adults and not associated with systemic symptoms like fever or ulcers.

questions.text: The following lesion was noticed in a patient with a history of involuntary weight loss. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by thickened, darkened patches of skin. These patches often have a velvety texture and can occur in various areas of the body, such as the neck, armpits, groin, and skin folds. Acanthosis nigricans is commonly associated with insulin resistance, which can be seen in conditions like type 2 diabetes or as a result of obesity.

Incorrect options :

Option B. Leser-Trélat sign refers to the sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses, which are benign skin growths. This sign is associated with underlying malignancies, particularly gastrointestinal cancers, but it does not specifically indicate involuntary weight loss.

Option C. Actinic keratosis is a precancerous skin condition characterized by rough, scaly patches that develop due to long-term sun exposure. While it can be associated with certain types of skin cancer, it is not directly related to involuntary weight loss.

Option D. Intertriginous Candida refers to a fungal infection that occurs in areas of skin-on-skin contact, such as the groin, armpits, or under the breasts. It typically presents as red, itchy, and moist lesions, but it is not typically associated with involuntary weight loss.

questions.text: What is incorrect regarding the displayed lesion?

choices.text: The lesions are infectious to seronegative individuals
Geniculate ganglion is involved in Ramsay Hunt syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bilaterally symmetrical dermatomal vesicular eruption:

  • Bilaterally symmetrical dermatomal vesicular eruption : This statement is incorrect.
  • The lesions shown are likely caused by a viral infection, such as herpes zoster (shingles).
  • The lesions shown are typically unilateral (on one side of the body) and follow a dermatomal distribution. A dermatome is an area of skin supplied by a single spinal nerve. Therefore, the eruption is usually unilateral, not bilaterally symmetrical.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The lesions are infectious to seronegative individuals: This statement is correct.. These viral lesions can be infectious and can spread to seronegative (non-immune) individuals.

Option B - Can be associated with meningoencephalitis: This statement is correct. The lesion shown, particularly if it involves the cranial nerves, can be associated with meningoencephalitis,

Option D - Geniculate ganglion is involved in Ramsay Hunt syndrome: This statement is correct.The geniculate ganglion, which is part of the facial nerve, is involved in this syndrome.

questions.text: The shown instrument is:
questions.solution:
Correct option : C

  • Humby's knife: This is the correct option. Humby's knife is a surgical instrument commonly used in plastic surgery used for harvesting Skin Graft

Incorrect options:

Option A Single cutting razor: This is an incorrect option. A single cutting razor typically refers to a handheld razor used for shaving or hair removal. It is not the instrument shown in the image.

Option B. Double cutting razor: This is an incorrect option. A double cutting razor is not a specific surgical instrument, but it can refer to a type of razor blade that has cutting edges on both sides. It is not the instrument shown in the image.

Option D. Finochietto knife: This is an incorrect option. Finochietto knife is not a commonly used surgical instrument, and it is not the instrument shown in the image.

questions.text: What is the most suitable approach to minimize the likelihood of keloid recurrence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option : A

  •  Intralesional steroids: This is the correct option. Intralesional steroid injections are commonly used in the management of keloids. Steroids, such as triamcinolone acetonide, are injected directly into the keloid to help reduce inflammation, shrink the scar tissue, and inhibit the overproduction of collagen. This can help prevent keloid recurrence after treatment.

Incorrect Options:

Option B:  Surgery: This is an incorrect option. Surgical removal of a keloid can be performed, but it carries a risk of keloid recurrence, as the surgical incision itself can trigger the formation of new keloid tissue. Surgery alone is not usually sufficient to prevent keloid recurrence, and it is often combined with other treatments like steroid injections or radiation therapy.

Option C: Cryotherapy: This is an incorrect option. Cryotherapy involves freezing the keloid with liquid nitrogen to destroy the abnormal tissue. While cryotherapy can be effective in reducing the size of the keloid, it may not address the underlying cause and is not considered the most reliable method for preventing keloid recurrence.

Option D: Electrocoagulation: This is an incorrect option. Electrocoagulation involves using an electric current to destroy the keloid tissue. While it can be used as a treatment for keloids, it is not considered the primary method for preventing keloid recurrence.

questions.text: What will be the diagnosis of an infant exhibiting the following condition, after a pharyngeal infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome:

  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS): This is the correct option.
  • SSSS is a bacterial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It typically affects infants and young children, especially those with weakened immune systems.
  • The condition is characterized by widespread erythema (redness) of the skin, followed by the development of large fluid-filled blisters that resemble scalded skin.
  • These blisters are fragile and can easily rupture, leaving behind raw, denuded skin.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Epidermolysis bullosa simplex: This is an incorrect option. Epidermolysis bullosa simplex is a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of fragile skin that is prone to blistering. The condition is not specifically associated with pharyngeal infections.

Option C - Impetigo contagiosa: It is characterized by the development of small, fluid-filled blisters that eventually burst, leaving behind honey-colored crusts.

Option D - Pemphigus foliaceus: This is an incorrect option. Pemphigus foliaceus is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by the presence of superficial blisters on the skin and mucous membranes

questions.text: Identify the penile lesion shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Pearly penile papule: Pearly penile papules are small, dome-shaped bumps that appear around the corona of the penis.
    • They are considered a normal anatomical variant and are not associated with any infection or disease.
    • The lesion shown in the image closely resembles the appearance of pearly penile papules.

Incorrect Options 

Option A. Genital wart: Genital warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and typically appear as small, raised, cauliflower-like growths on the genital area. They can vary in size and may be pink, flesh-colored, or grayish in appearance. The lesion shown in the image does not resemble the typical appearance of genital warts.

Option C. Balanitis: Balanitis refers to inflammation of the glans penis, typically caused by an infection or irritation. It can result in redness, swelling, and discomfort of the penis. The lesion shown in the image does not exhibit signs of inflammation commonly seen in balanitis.

Option D. Sebaceous gland prominence: Sebaceous gland prominence, also known as Fordyce spots, refers to the visible sebaceous glands on the skin. They appear as small, yellowish or white bumps and are commonly found on the genitals and other areas of the body. The lesion shown in the image does not resemble the typical appearance of sebaceous gland prominence.

questions.text: The Lesions shown below are the characteristic of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Molluscum contagiosum

 

Explanation:

 

The lesions described as small, dome-shaped, flesh-colored or pearly papules with a central umbilication are classically seen in Molluscum Contagiosum, a viral skin infection caused by a poxvirus.

Feature Description
Lesion appearance Smooth, dome-shaped papules with central dimple
Colour Flesh-colored, pink, or pearly-white
Size Typically 2–5 mm in diameter
Common in Children, sexually active adults, immunocompromised
Location Face, trunk, axillae, genital area
Cause Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV, a poxvirus)

 

Chicken pox (Option B): Lesions are vesicular, appear in crops, and progress from papules to vesicles to crusts — not dome-shaped papules.

 

Pemphigus (Option C): Autoimmune blistering disorder — presents with flaccid bullae and erosions, not pearly papules.

 

Common warts (Option D): Caused by HPV — lesions are verrucous, rough, and hyperkeratotic, not smooth or dome-shaped.

questions.text: The narrowest part of airway in an infant is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Subglottis:

  • Subglottis: This option is correct. The subglottis is the narrowest part of the airway in an infant, which is located below the glottis.

  • Rima glottidis: Space between between 2 true cords
  • Ventricle: Space between false cords above and true cords below
  • Elongation from ventricle: Saccule

Incorrect options:

Option A - Supraglottis: This option is incorrect. The supraglottis is the region above the glottis and is not the narrowest part of the airway in an infant.

Option B - Glottis: This option is incorrect. While the glottis is a critical part of the airway, it is not the narrowest part of the airway in an infant.

Option D - Epiglottis: This option is incorrect. The epiglottis is a flap of tissue that covers the glottis during swallowing and protects the airway. However, it is not the narrowest part of the airway in an infant.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 15-year-old male patient who has a nasal mass extending to the cheek, causing one-sided obstruction and occasional nosebleeds?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Angiofibroma:

  • Given the age and the gender of the patient the most likely diagnosis is nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, it is a rare and benign tumor of nasopharynx exclusively seen in juvenile age group. It is the most common tumor of the nasopharynx and is exclusively seen in males. Angiofibroma is a highly vascular, and present with epistaxis.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Nasal polyp: Nasal polyps are benign growths that usually arise from the lining of the nasal cavity and sinuses. They do not readily cause epistaxis.

Option C - Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma typically occurs in the nasopharynx (Fossa of Rosenmuller). It is usually associated with cervical lymphadenopathy and Trotters triad.

Option D - Inverted Papilloma: Inverted papilloma is a benign tumor that arises from the lining of the nasal cavity. While it can cause nasal obstruction and ocassional nasal bleed,it is more common in males of 40-70 years of age.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is high tracheostomy performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Carcinoma larynx:

  • Carcinoma larynx: This option is correct. A high tracheostomy may be performed in cases of carcinoma of the larynx to provide an adequate airway below the tumor.
  • Tracheostomy
  • Surgical opening in the trachea is called a tracheostomy.
  • If a tracheostomy is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring. This is called a High tracheostomy. Mainly done in patients with total laryngectomy.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Laryngeal papilloma: This option is incorrect. Laryngeal papilloma is a condition characterized by the presence of benign growths in the larynx. It does not require a high tracheostomy.

Option C - Bilateral vocal fold palsy: This option is incorrect. Bilateral vocal fold palsy refers to the paralysis or weakness of both vocal folds. It does not require a high tracheostomy.

Option D - Laryngomalacia: This option is incorrect. Laryngomalacia is a condition in infants where the tissues of the larynx are floppy, leading to partial airway obstruction. It does not typically require a high tracheostomy.

questions.text: All are parts of the Hypopharynx except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D 

  • Vallecula: This option is correct. The vallecula is part of the oropharynx, not the hypopharynx.

Hypopharynx

  • There are three subdivisions of the hypopharynx. They are (3Ps)
  • Pyriform fossa: These are two depressions on the lateral sides of the aryepiglottic folds. They are also known as the smuggler's pouch.
  • Post cricoid region: It is a depression in the midline below the arytenoids.
  • Posterior pharyngeal wall: It is a continuous wall of the hypopharynx.
  • The hypopharynx: The Hypopharynx continues down to the esophagus.

Incorrect options: 

Option A - Posterior pharyngeal wall: The posterior pharyngeal wall is part of the hypopharynx.

Option B - Pyriform Sinus: The pyriform sinuses are part of the hypopharynx.

Option C - Post-cricoid area: The post-cricoid area is part of the hypopharynx.

questions.text: In a 3-year-old child, who has severe Sensorineural deafness and does not show any improvement with hearing aids, but has intact auditory nerve function, which procedure is recommended as the first choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cochlear implant: 

  • Cochlear implant: Cochlear implantation is the preferred procedure for children with profound sensorineural deafness who do not benefit from hearing aids.

Incorrect options

Option A - Hearing Aids: Hearing aids are not effective for profound sensorineural deafness.

Option B - BAHA (Bone Anchored Hearing Aid): Bone-Anchored Hearing Aids are often used for individuals with conductive or mixed hearing loss, where traditional hearing aids may not be effective due to problems with sound transmission through the middle ear.

Option D - Auditory Brainstem Implant: Auditory Brainstem Implants (ABIs) are typically considered for individuals with severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss who are not candidates for cochlear implants due to abnormalities in the cochlea or auditory nerve.

questions.text: A patient presented with a 2 day history of fever and difficulty in swallowing. On examination there was swelling seen in the oropharynx pushing tonsil to midline and swelling over the upper part of neck. What is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation described, the most likely diagnosis is 2. Parapharyngeal abscess.

Here's an explanation of the options:

  1. Quinsy (Peritonsillar Abscess): Quinsy is an abscess that forms in the peritonsillar space, which is located around the tonsils. It can cause severe throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and the tonsil on one side may be pushed toward the midline due to the accumulation of pus. While it shares some similarities with parapharyngeal abscess, the key difference is that quinsy specifically involves the peritonsillar space.

  2. Parapharyngeal Abscess: A parapharyngeal abscess is an infection and collection of pus located in the parapharyngeal space, which is situated behind the pharynx (throat) and extends into the upper part of the neck. It often presents with fever, difficulty swallowing, and swelling over the upper part of the neck, as described in the scenario.

  3. Retropharyngeal Abscess: A retropharyngeal abscess is an infection and collection of pus in the retropharyngeal space, which is located behind the throat and in front of the cervical spine. It can also cause difficulty swallowing and neck swelling. However, it typically presents in a different anatomical location compared to the parapharyngeal abscess.

  4. Tonsillitis: Tonsillitis is an infection or inflammation of the tonsils, which can cause sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing. While tonsillitis may involve swelling of the tonsils, it doesn't typically cause the specific neck swelling described in the scenario.

questions.text: Deep lobe of parotid gland swelling presents at
questions.solution:
Correct Option D 

  • Parapharyngeal Space: This option is correct. The deep lobe of the parotid gland can extend into the parapharyngeal space, leading to swelling in that region.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Below the ear lobe: This option is incorrect. Swelling below the ear lobe is not specific to the deep lobe of the parotid gland.

Option B - Cheek: This option is incorrect. While parotid gland swelling can cause cheek enlargement, it is not specific to the deep lobe.

Option C - Temporal lobe: This option is incorrect. The temporal lobe is a part of the brain and is not related to parotid gland swelling.

questions.text: Which muscle in the larynx is essential for saving lives as it retracts the vocal cords to enable breathing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B

  • Posterior Cricoarytenoid: This option is correct. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is the only abductor muscle of the vocal cords, meaning it pulls them apart for breathing, allowing air to pass through the larynx.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cricothyroid: This option is incorrect. The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for adjusting the tension of the vocal cords, but it does not pull them back for breathing.

Option C - Lateral Cricoarytenoid: This option is incorrect. The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is involved in adducting the vocal cords for phonation, not for breathing.

Option D - Transverse Arytenoid: This option is incorrect. The transverse arytenoid muscle is also involved in adducting the vocal cords for phonation, not for breathing.

questions.text: What category of malignancy do rodent ulcers belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Basal cell carcinoma:

  • Rodent ulcers are another term for basal cell carcinomas, which are the most common type of skin cancer.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect as Rodent ulcer is a type of basal cell carcinoma of skin.

questions.text: In patients with Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma, what is the primary cause of hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Serous otitis media:

  • Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma can lead to obstruction or dysfunction of the Eustachian tube due to tumor growth. This obstruction can impair the normal ventilation and drainage of the middle ear, leading to the accumulation of fluid (serous otitis media) in the middle ear cavity, causing conductive deafness in these patients. (A component of trotter’s triad)

Trotter's Triad:

  • Conductive deafness due to block of eustachian tube
  • Ipsilateral temporo-parietal neuralgia due to 5 nerve involvement
  • Palatal paralysis (10 nerve involvement)

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are not the primary cause of deafness in patients with NPC.

questions.text: What is the most frequently reported symptom in patients with Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cervical lymphadenopathy:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma often presents with cervical lymphadenopathy as an early sign. The most common lymph node involved is LN between the angle of the jaw and mastoid and LN along the spinal accessory and in the posterior triangle of the neck in HO's triangle.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hearing Loss: While conductive hearing loss can occur in patients with Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma, it is not the most frequently reported symptom. Hearing loss is more commonly associated with conditions affecting the middle or inner ear rather than nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option C - Airway Obstruction: Airway obstruction can occur in advanced cases of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, but it is not typically the most frequently reported symptom.

Option D - Epistaxis: Epistaxis, or nosebleeds, can be a symptom of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, but it is not the most frequently reported symptom.

questions.text: What are the structures that are not visible during indirect laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Anterior Commissure:

  • This option is correct. The anterior commissure, which is the point of contact between the vocal cords anteriorly, is not directly visible during indirect laryngoscopy.
  • Can be seen in some cases but may be difficult to see if the epiglottis is overhanging.

Incorrect Options;

Option B - Tracheal rings:

  • This option is incorrect. Tracheal rings through the glottic chink (Rima glottides is visible)

Option C - Epiglottis:

  • This option is incorrect. The epiglottis, which is a flap of tissue located at the base of the tongue, is visible during indirect laryngoscopy.

Option D - False Vocal Cord:

  • This option is incorrect. The false vocal cord, also known as the ventricular fold, is visible during indirect laryngoscopy.

questions.text: What are the initial signs of vocal fold growth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • The earliest symptom of vocal fold growth or vocal cord lesions is typically a change in voice quality or hoarseness.
  • This change in voice may be characterized by a raspy, breathy, or rough quality. It may also be accompanied by a decrease in vocal range or difficulty in producing certain sounds or pitches.
  • The correct option is B - Change of voice.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Cough: While vocal fold growth or vocal cord lesions can sometimes lead to a cough, it is not typically an early symptom.

Option C - Fatigue voice: Fatigue or vocal fatigue may occur as a result of vocal fold growth, but it is not an early symptom.

Option D - Pain: Pain is not typically an early symptom of vocal fold growth or vocal cord lesions unless there is an underlying inflammatory or infectious process.

questions.text: Parotid gland is supplied by which nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct option - B Glossopharyngeal:

  • Glossopharyngeal: The glossopharyngeal nerve supply the parotid gland.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Facial Nerve: The facial nerve does not supply the parotid gland.

Option C - Vagus Nerve: The vagus nerve does not supply the parotid gland.

Option D - Hypoglossal Nerve: The hypoglossal nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the muscles of the tongue and does not supply the parotid gland.

questions.text: All are grounds for divorce except :
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Poverty:

  • Poverty is not a ground for divorce.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Adultery: Adultery is ground for divorce.

Option B - Incurable Leprosy: Incurable Leprosy is not a grounds for divorce.

Option D - Insanity: Insanity is a grounds for divorce.

questions.text: What is the appropriate IPC section for the act of inducing abortion without the consent of the woman?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IPC Section 313:

  • In the Indian Penal Code (IPC), Section 313 deals with the act of causing miscarriage without a woman's consent.

  • This section makes it a criminal offense to cause a woman to miscarry against her will. It states that anyone who causes a woman, who is with child, to miscarry without her consent can be punished with imprisonment that may extend up to ten years, along with a fine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IPC Section 312: It deals with voluntarily causing a miscarriage and carries a lesser punishment compared to Section 313.

Option C - IPC Section 314: Whoever, with intent to cause the miscarriage of a woman with child, does any act which causes the death of such woman.

Option D - IPC Section 315: Act done with intent to prevent child being born alive or to cause it to die after birth.

questions.text: In case of corrosive acid ingestion, stomach is opened along the?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Greater curvature:

  • In cases of corrosive acid ingestion, if surgical intervention is necessary to address severe damage, the stomach is typically surgically opened along the greater curvature.

  • Here's an explanation of the correct option and the other options:

    • Lesser Curvature: The maximum damage is on the lesser curvature

    • Greater Curvature:

      • Because, in cases like acid or corrosive poisoning, the maximum damage is on the lesser curvature (Magenstrasse).

      • To examine the lesser curvature, it opened from greater curvature by the double ligature method.

    • Vertical: The term "vertical" is not typically used to describe the surgical opening of the stomach. Instead, surgical approaches are often described in relation to specific anatomical features like the curvatures.

    • Pylorus: The pylorus is the lower part of the stomach that connects to the small intestine. In cases of corrosive acid ingestion, the surgical focus is often on the affected areas of the stomach, and the pylorus may or may not be involved depending on the extent of the damage.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation for the correct answer.

questions.text: Inhaling the cloth soaked in drug is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Huffing:

  • Huffing refers to the act of inhaling volatile substances or drugs by saturating a cloth or other material and then inhaling the fumes.

  • Huffing is a form of inhalant abuse, and it can have harmful effects on the body, including intoxication and potential damage to the respiratory system.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bagging: Bagging refers to a method of inhaling substances by placing them inside a bag and then inhaling or breathing in the vapors. The bag is typically held over the nose and mouth, allowing the person to inhale the substance contained within the bag

Option B - Spraying: Spraying typically involves the dispersal of liquid substances in a fine mist or spray form. 

Option D - Sniffing: Sniffing refers to the act of inhaling substances directly through the nose.

questions.text: What is the responsibility of the doctor in recording the dying declaration of a victim affected by a fire?

choices.text: To record the statement even in the presence of magistrate
Put the person under oath before declaration

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - To assess compos mentis:

  • When a dying declaration is being recorded, the role of the doctor is to assess the mental capacity of the person making the statement, also known as "compos mentis."
  • The doctor evaluates whether the person is of sound mind and capable of providing a coherent and reliable statement.
  • This assessment helps determine the admissibility and credibility of the dying declaration as evidence in legal proceedings.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - To record the statement even in the presence of a magistrate: It is not the role of the doctor to record the statement in the presence of a magistrate

Option C - Cross-examine the person: Cross-examination is a legal procedure conducted by legal professionals, such as lawyers or prosecutors. It is not the role of the doctor to cross-examine the person giving the dying declaration.

Option D - Put the person under oath before declaration: The doctor's role in recording a dying declaration does not involve putting the person under oath.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent statements accurately describe tremors?   	PD is characterized by resting tremor 	Tremor consist of alternate contraction of agonist and antagonist muscle in an oscillating rhythmic manner 	Essential tremor is an uncommon movement disorder affecting 5% of the population 	Normal individuals can have physiologic tremors that manifest as mild high frequency, postural or action tremors
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1,2,4 only: 

True statements about tremors are:

  • PD is characterized by resting tremor:Resting tremor is a hallmark feature of Parkinson's disease (PD). Tremor consists of alternate contraction of agonist and antagonist muscles in an oscillating rhythmic manner: Tremors involve rhythmic oscillations of body parts and are typically caused by alternating contractions of agonist and antagonist muscles.
  • Normal individuals can have physiologic tremors that manifest as mild high frequency, postural, or action tremors: Physiologic tremors are normal variations in hand or body tremors that can occur in healthy individuals. They are typically mild and high frequency, occurring during certain postures or actions such as holding a position against gravity or during fine motor tasks.

 

Incorrect statement

  • Essential tremor is an uncommon movement disorder affecting 5% of the population: Essential tremor is actually a common movement disorder, around 5% to 10% of individuals, especially in older age groups. Essential tremor is characterized by postural or action tremors, often involving the hands, head, or voice.

questions.text: In a medical camp established on a military base, a 20-year-old military recruit is discovered to have an HbA1C level of 6.1% and a fasting blood glucose of 120 mg/dL. The individual does not have a familial background of diabetes mellitus and displays no indications or symptoms of diabetes. The general physical examination shows no noteworthy findings. Which of the following options most accurately characterizes the blood glucose levels in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Impaired Glucose tolerance: 

  • The patient in the scenario has an HbA1C level of 6.1% and a fasting blood glucose level of 120 mg/dL. These values fall within the range that indicates impaired glucose tolerance (IGT).
  • Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) is a condition in which blood glucose levels are higher than normal but not high enough to be classified as diabetes mellitus.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Normal- Normal blood glucose levels typically fall within a range of 70-99 mg/dL for fasting blood glucose and below 5.7% for HbA1C.

Option C - Diabetes Mellitus- Diabetes mellitus is diagnosed when fasting blood glucose levels are consistently above 126 mg/dL or HbA1C levels are equal to or higher than 6.5%.

Option D - Maturity onset diabetes in Young (MODY)- Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is a type of diabetes characterized by a strong family history, early onset before the age of 25, and a specific genetic etiology.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of fulminant diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Viruses:

  • Fulminant diabetes, also known as fulminant type 1 diabetes or acute-onset type 1 diabetes, is a rare and rapidly progressing form of diabetes characterized by severe hyperglycemia and a rapid loss of insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas.
  • Viruses, particularly enteroviruses such as Coxsackie B virus, have been implicated as a potential cause of fulminant diabetes. These viruses can infect and damage the pancreatic beta cells, leading to their destruction and subsequent loss of insulin production.

Incorrect options

Option B -Diabetic Ketoacidosis 

  • DKA occurs primarily in individuals with established diabetes, particularly in type 1 diabetes, and is characterized by the presence of hyperglycemia, ketosis, and acidosis.

Option C - Non-ketotic Hyperosmolar Coma

  • Non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma is characterized by extremely high blood glucose levels and severe dehydration. However, it is not the most common cause of fulminant diabetes.

Option D - Autoimmunity

  • In the case of fulminant diabetes, the rapid onset and progression of the disease suggest a different underlying cause, such as viral infection, rather than the gradual autoimmune destruction of beta cells seen in typical type 1 diabetes.

questions.text:
Which of the following joints are commonly involved in diabetes?

MC joint involved in diabetes is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Metatarsophalangeal joints: 

  • In diabetes, one of the commonly affected joints is the Charcot joint, particularly the metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joints.
  • Charcot joint mainly involves the foot is frequently affected in individuals with diabetes.
  • Complications such as peripheral neuropathy, and poor circulation (peripheral arterial disease) can lead to foot-related issues such as ulcers, infections, and joint deformities.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Ankle- While complications of diabetes can affect the ankle joint indirectly, such as peripheral neuropathy leading to instability and increased risk of ankle injuries, the ankle joint itself is not a primary site of involvement in diabetes.

Option B - Knee- Diabetes can lead to various complications and conditions that may affect the knee joint indirectly, such as diabetic neuropathy or diabetic arthropathy (Charcot joint), but the knee joint itself is not a primary site of involvement.

Option C - Shoulder- Shoulder joint involvement is not commonly associated with diabetes. Diabetes-related joint problems typically manifest in weight-bearing joints and those subjected to excessive pressure, such as the foot.

questions.text: Which type of insulin should be administered to manage a 32-year-old male patient with a medical history of peptic ulcer disease and diabetes mellitus, who presents to the emergency department complaining of nausea, abdominal pain, and lethargy for the past two days? The patient also reports occasional dark, tarry stools. Laboratory tests indicate elevated blood glucose levels and a high anion gap metabolic acidosis on an arterial blood gas sample.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Regular insulin: 

  • Regular insulin, also known as short-acting insulin, is the most appropriate choice for managing DKA.
  • Regular insulin is the correct choice because it has an onset of action of approximately 30 minutes, peaks in 2 to 4 hours, and lasts for about 6 to 8 hours. Its slower onset and longer duration of action make it suitable for managing the prolonged hyperglycemia and metabolic acidosis associated with DKA.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Lispro insulin is a rapid-acting insulin with a quick onset of action but a shorter duration compared to regular insulin. It is commonly used to manage postprandial glucose spikes in individuals with diabetes.

Option C - Glargine insulin is a long-acting insulin that provides a steady release of insulin over an extended period (approximately 24 hours). It is used for basal insulin coverage. .

Option D - Aspart insulin is a rapid-acting insulin similar to lispro insulin. It has a rapid onset and shorter duration of action, making it less suitable for the management of DKA

questions.text: Which of the following has a slow onset of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: 

  • Glargine insulin is a long-acting insulin that is characterized by a slow onset of action, typically taking about 1 to 2 hours to begin working. It is designed to provide a steady release of insulin over an extended period (approximately 24 hours). This slow onset and prolonged duration make it suitable for providing basal insulin coverage.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Lispro insulin is a rapid-acting insulin that has a quick onset of action, typically within 15 minutes of administration. It is used to control postprandial glucose spikes after meals. Unlike glargine, lispro insulin has a fast onset rather than a slow onset.

Option C: Regular insulin, also known as short-acting insulin, has an onset of action of approximately 30 minutes. It is used for mealtime coverage or in combination with long-acting insulin for basal coverage. It is not characterized by a slow onset like glargine.

Option D: NPH (Neutral Protamine Hagedorn) insulin is an intermediate-acting insulin. It has a slower onset compared to rapid-acting insulins but is not specifically known for having a slow onset like glargine. NPH insulin typically takes about 1 to 2 hours to start working

questions.text: What is the main physical finding of prolactinoma that follows galactorrhea in a 19-year-old nulligravida woman who has been experiencing milk discharge from her nipples for the last 5 months and is diagnosed with prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bitemporal hemianopia: 

  • Prolactinomas are benign pituitary tumors that secrete excessive prolactin. When large enough, they can compress the optic chiasm, where optic nerve fibers partially cross. This pressure disrupts the outer (temporal) visual fields of both eyes, leading to bitemporal hemianopia—a condition where patients lose peripheral vision but retain central vision. Bitemporal hemianopia is a key physical finding in large prolactinomas and often prompts further diagnostic imaging to confirm the tumor's presence.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Anovulatory cycles- While prolactinomas can disrupt normal menstrual cycles, leading to anovulatory cycles, it is not the characteristic physical finding after galactorrhea.

Option C: Amenorrhea- Prolactinomas can cause hormonal imbalances, including elevated prolactin levels, which can disrupt normal menstrual cycles and lead to amenorrhea. However, it is not the characteristic physical finding after galactorrhea.

Option D: Infertility- Prolactinomas can disrupt normal hormonal balance and interfere with ovulation, leading to difficulties in conceiving. However, infertility is not the characteristic physical finding after galactorrhea

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his son. He complains of being unable to move his left arm and leg. According to his son, the patient was reading a book half an hour ago when he realized he couldn't lift his left arm to pick up another book. As he tried to move away from the table, he noticed that his left leg also became very weak. Additionally, he experienced double vision. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His body temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), blood pressure is 165/100 mmHg, pulse is 85 beats/min, and he has a respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min. During the examination, it is observed that the patient has drooping of the right eyelid and his right eye is directed downwards and to the side.  When requested to smile, there is a drooping of the left corner of the mouth. The strength of the left upper and lower limbs is rated as 3 out of 5, whereas the strength of the right upper and lower limbs is rated as 5 out of 5.  Which region of his brain has experienced ischemia among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C -  Midbrain:

  • The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with a lacunar infarct, which is a small, localized ischemic stroke that occurs in the deep structures of the brain.
  • Midbrain, also known as the mesencephalon, is a region of the brainstem that plays a role in coordinating motor movements and controlling eye movements.
  • In this case, the patient's symptoms, including weakness on the left side of the body and abnormal eye movements (ptosis, downward and lateral deviation of the right eye), suggest an ischemic event affecting the midbrain.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Inner capsule- Damage to the inner capsule can cause motor and sensory deficits. However, in this case, the patient's symptoms are not consistent with an infarct in the inner capsule.

Option B - Medulla- While a stroke in the medulla can cause various neurological deficits, the patient's symptoms, such as weakness in the left arm and leg and double vision, are not specific to a medullary infarct.

Option D - Occipital lobe- Patient’s visual symptoms of double vision are more likely related to the involvement of the midbrain and its control over eye movements rather than a specific occipital lobe infarct
